Literature Review: Functional trait–based ecology has emerged as a promising approach to understanding animal invasions, with growing empirical research in this field. This literature review aims to provide a comprehensive examination of the role of functional traits in mediating animal invasions, incorporating comparative phylogenetic approaches and examining assemblages. We discuss the importance of time since introduction, broad environmental tolerances, life history traits, and phenotypic plasticity in mediating the success of animal alien species at various stages of invasion. Our review highlights the need for further research in this area, particularly in incorporating comparative phylogenetic approaches and examining assemblages. We also discuss the importance of considering the role of introduction effort in mediating the success of animal alien species.
